H0.text: After a drought, a population of trees would most benefit from having serotinous cones, which are seed enclosures that require intense heat to open.

H1.text: After a heat wave, a population of trees would most benefit from having serotinous cones, because these seed enclosures require intense heat to open.

H2.text: After a forest fire, a population of trees would most benefit from having serotinous cones, because the intense heat from the fire triggers the cones to open and release seeds.

H3.text: After a tornado, a population of trees would most benefit from having serotinous cones, because the intense heat from the tornado triggers the cones to open and release seeds.

A4.text: The most common and best studied trigger is fire, and the term serotiny is used to refer to this specific case.

A5.text: The effect of this adaptation is to ensure that seed release occurs not in response to fire, but in response to the onset of rains following fire.

A6.text: Many Pinus species adapted to this fire-prone environment with serotinous pine cones.

A7.text: Fire occurred more frequently than it does currently, and plant growth was high enough to create an abundance of flammable material.
